qas.question: What nation's model gives the power of the high court to the legistlature?
What is the name of China's high court which sits as a legislative committee?

answers.text: Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPCSC)

qas.question: Current decisions by the NPCSC do not affect what?

answers.text: cases which have already been decided

qas.question: Hong Kong's legal system was traditionally based on what?
Macau's legal system comes from what tradition?

plausible_answers.text: Standing Committee of the National People's Congress

qas.question: What is the NCPSC also known as?
What country can interpret the laws of Macau and China?
What country is the Chinese legal system based on?

context: In most nations with constitutions modelled after the <a0_0><b7_0>Soviet Union<b7_0/><a0_0/>, the legislature was given the power of being the court of last resort. In the People's Republic of China, the final power to interpret the law is vested in the <a1_0><b5_0>Standing Committee of the National People's Congress<b5_0/> (NPCSC)<a1_0/>. This power includes the power to interpret the basic laws of <b6_0>Hong Kong<b6_0/> and Macau, the constitutional documents of the two special administrative regions which are <a3_0>common law<a3_0/> and <a4_0>Portuguese-based legal system<a4_0/> jurisdictions respectively. This power is a legislative power and not a judicial one in that an interpretation by the NPCSC does not affect <a2_0>cases which have already been decided<a2_0/>.
